importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The GPEI will face a 30 percent budget reduction starting in 2026, affecting the sustainability of polio eradication activities.
The $1.7 billion funding gap is projected through 2029, creating long-term financial instability in polio eradication efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The GPEI faces a sustained funding shortfall from 2026 through 2029, threatening the continuity of polio eradication programs.

keyTakeAways: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) is facing a $1.7 billion funding shortfall through 2029, primarily due to reduced foreign aid, especially from the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom.
The WHO's director of polio eradication, Jamal Ahmed, warns that funding reductions mean critical activities like vaccination and surveillance will be curtailed.
The GPEI plans to prioritize high-risk areas such as Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio cases have been reported, and adopt cost-effective strategies like fractional dosing of vaccines.
Vaccine-derived polio has been recorded in 149 cases across countries, including Nigeria, highlighting risks in vaccine distribution and immunity gaps.
Despite the funding shortfall, experts affirm that polio eradication remains feasible with sustained global commitment and integrated health programming.
Wild polio cases have declined since 2024, but the persistence of the virus in Afghanistan and Pakistan remains a major public health challenge.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A form of polio caused by mutations in weakened viruses used in oral vaccines, spreading in unvaccinated communities.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It poses a significant risk in areas with low vaccination coverage, such as in Nigeria.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A $1.7 billion funding shortfall threatens the Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI), which includes the World Health Organization and the Gates Foundation. The shortfall, driven by reduced foreign aid from the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom, will result in a 30% budget reduction starting in 2026 and a critical gap through 2029. The GPEI is responding by focusing resources on high-risk regions like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio cases are reported, and adopting cost-saving strategies such as fractional dosing. While vaccine-derived polio has been recorded in Nigeria and other countries, global health officials emphasize that sustained vaccination and surveillance are essential to achieve eradication. Despite the funding crisis, experts maintain that eradication remains feasible with continued international cooperation.
title: WHO warns $1.7bn funding shortfall threatens polio eradication efforts
